channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Twitter Network Uses Fake Accounts to Promote Netanyahu, Israel Watchdog Finds
item.media:description: A campaign billboard for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in Jerusalem.
item.description: A network of hundreds of social media accounts, many of them fake, was used to smear opponents of the Israeli prime minister, investigators found.
item.dc:creator: RONEN BERGMAN

item.title: Erdogan, Turkey’s Leader, Staring at Major Electoral Defeat
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan after voting in municipal elections in Istanbul on Sunday.
item.description: Istanbul, the president’s hometown and stronghold, seemed poised to slip through his fingers in municipal elections that signaled a political earthquake.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Chinese Dissidents Feel Heat of Beijing’s Wrath. Even in Canada.
item.media:description: Sheng Xue has been the victim of a relentless smear campaign that experts say has all the markings of a coordinated attack by the Chinese Communist Party.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: She thought she would be safe in Toronto. Then she began speaking out against the Chinese government and became the victim of a lurid smear campaign.
item.dc:creator: CATHERINE PORTER

item.title: Japan’s New Era Gets a Name, but No One Can Agree What It Means
item.media:description: Chief Cabinet Secretary Yoshihide Suga of Japan revealing the new imperial era’s name in Tokyo on Monday.
item.description: The era of the incoming emperor, Naruhito, will be known as Reiwa, a term that can mean “order and peace,” “auspicious harmony” and “joyful harmony.”
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: China Bans All Types of Fentanyl, Fulfilling Pledge to Trump
item.media:description: Chinese officials said in Beijing on Monday that they would treat all variants of the opioid fentanyl as controlled substances, fulfilling a promise President Xi Jinping made to President Trump last year.
item.description: Carrying out a promise made to President Trump, China announced that it would treat all variations of the opioid fentanyl as controlled substances.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Nepal Storm Kills Dozens and Injures Hundreds
item.description: “Dead bodies are scattered everywhere,” an official said, as rescuers continued to search through the debris.
item.dc:creator: BHADRA SHARMA

item.title: Political Handlers With Trump Ties Take Their Election Playbooks to Africa
item.media:description: Riva Levinson, a political consultant once employed by Paul Manafort, has worked for both opposition parties and governments in Africa.
item.description: American campaign consultants, including one mentored by Paul Manafort, are increasingly being hired by African candidates to help them win at the polls in still fragile democracies.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: Natalia Fileva, Russian Aviation Tycoon, Dies in Plane Crash
item.media:description: The private plane crashed near Darmstadt, Germany, on Sunday, killing all those on board.
item.media:credit: Boris Roessler/DPA, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Ms. Fileva, who was considered one of Russia’s richest women, died on Sunday when a private plane on which she was traveling crashed in Germany.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES

item.title: Vietnamese Woman Sentenced in Kim Jong-nam Assassination
item.description: The woman, Doan Thi Huong, 30, pleaded guilty to the lesser charge of causing bodily harm, in a killing that many officials believe was set up by North Korean agents.
item.dc:creator: SHARON TAN and RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Iran Hit With 3rd Major Flood in 2 Weeks
item.media:description: Iranian soldiers helping civilians in a flooded area near the city of Ahvaz, in Iran’s Khuzestan Province, on Sunday.
item.description: The authorities ordered the evacuation of flood-ravaged cities in western Iran. The Red Crescent said contact had been lost with much of the region.
item.dc:creator: AGENCE FRANCE-PRESSE

item.title: Algeria’s Strongman President to Step Down
item.description: Amid months of unprecedented protests across Algeria — the largest anti-government demonstrations in over 30 years — President Abdelaziz Bouteflika has announced that he will resign by April 28 after ruling the country for 20 years.

item.title: Algeria’s Ruler, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, Agrees to Step Down
item.description: Abdelaziz Bouteflika, who has ruled Algeria for 20 years, appears to have yielded to mass protests demanding his resignation.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: In Ukraine Presidential Runoff, It’s Comic Versus Chocolate King
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky playing table tennis at his campaign headquarters after voting concluded in Kiev.
item.description: An actor with no political experience easily finished first in Ukraine’s election, and will face the incumbent president in an April 21 runoff.
item.dc:creator: IULIIA MENDEL and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: This Tarantula Became a Scientific Celebrity. Was It Poached From the Wild?
item.media:description: A new species of tarantula, Birupes simoroxigorum, was described from specimens alleged to have been taken illegally from Malaysia.
item.description: Controversy over a new spider species has resurrected thorny ethical questions about scientists and their specimens.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL NUWER

item.title: Singapore Plans Law to Fight False News, but Critics Fear Repression
item.media:description: Journalists working during the summit meeting between President Trump and the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, in Singapore last year.
item.description: The government says the legislation would combat misinformation that harms the public interest, but rights advocates worry that it could be used to mute free speech.
item.dc:creator: MIKE IVES and RAYMOND ZHONG

item.title: 30 Die Fighting Forest Fire in China
item.media:description: Smoke from a forest fire in Liangshan Yi Autonomous Prefecture in Sichuan Province, China, on Monday.
item.description: The death toll was believed to be the highest for firefighters in the country since 2015, after shifting winds fanned the flames in Sichuan Province.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: Joe Biden, Turkey, Nipsey Hussle: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: Joe Biden, pictured last month, is known for his close physical contact with women and men.
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS STANFORD

item.title: Brexit, U.S. Border, India: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain speaking to lawmakers on Friday.
item.media:credit: Mark Duffy/House of Commons, via Associated Press
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: MELINA DELKIC

item.title: Pope Francis Warns Trump About Walls After Morocco Visit
item.media:description: Worshipers reaching out to Pope Francis on Sunday as he left an arena in Rabat, Morocco, after celebrating a Mass there.
item.description: Urging compassion for migrants, the pope said those who close borders “will become prisoners of the walls that they build.”
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Report Says Algeria’s President Is Preparing to Resign
item.media:description: Demonstrators carrying national flags and banners during a protest in Algiers on Friday to demand the resignation of President Abdelaziz Bouteflika.
item.description: After weeks of protests and a call by the army chief to declare him unfit, President Abdelaziz Bouteflika is ready to step down, according to a privately owned TV network.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Russia’s Military Mission Creep Advances to a New Front: Africa
item.media:description: New recruits for the Central African Republic’s armed forces. Members have trained with Russian consultants as part of Moscow’s growing influence across Africa.
item.description: In an influence campaign that is worrying the Pentagon, Russia’s weapons sales, military training programs and security agreements are growing across Africa.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Brexit, Indian Elections, the Kardashians: Your Monday Briefing
item.media:description: Pro-Brexit protesters outside Parliament on Friday.
item.description: Let us help you start your day.
item.dc:creator: ALISHA HARIDASANI GUPTA

item.title: Storm Kills at Least 25 in Nepal, Officials Say
item.media:description: A victim of a thunderstorm at a hospital in Parsha district, Nepal, on Sunday.
item.description: Prime Minister Khadga Prasad Oli of Nepal said in a Twitter message that he had received a report of 25 people killed and 400 injured.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Italian Minister Pans Hit Song by an Immigrant’s Son
item.media:description: Mr. Mahoud at a cafe in Milan.
item.media:credit: Elisabetta Zavoli for The New York Times
item.description: Interior Minister Matteo Salvini of the anti-immigrant League party was not a fan of the Italian-language rap tune with a Middle Eastern flavor that won a song contest.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: Where Prisoners Can Lock Their Cells for Privacy, and Guards Are Told to Knock
item.media:description: The policies at the Berwyn prison in Wrexham, Wales, are meant to improve confinement conditions and rehabilitation.
item.description: As part of a strategy to improve confinement conditions and boost rehabilitation, a prison in Wales allows inmates laptops and the ability to can lock their cells for privacy.
item.dc:creator: ILIANA MAGRA

item.title: Freed From ISIS, Syrians Struggle to Rebuild Raqqa
item.description: The Syrian city was liberated from the Islamic State more than a year and a half ago, but rebuilding is slow and hope is fading.
item.dc:creator: BEN C. SOLOMON and BEN LAFFIN

item.title: Inside ISIS’ Former Capital: The Forgotten People of Raqqa
item.description: We went back to Raqqa, which was liberated more than a year and a half ago, to see how people were getting by. We saw Syrians dancing to celebrate the final battle against ISIS. But destruction is still all around and progress is slow. The fear now is that frustration could breed radicalization once again.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Taiwan Condemns China After Fighter Jets Cross Maritime Line
item.description: Denouncing a “provocative” move, a Taiwanese official says Beijing should “not be an international troublemaker.”
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: 3 Teenage Migrants Are Charged in Malta With Hijacking Ship at Sea
item.media:description: Armed forces and migrants aboard the tanker El Hiblu 1 in Valletta, Malta, on Thursday.
item.description: The suspects, said to be a sociology major and two high school students, allegedly forced a small tanker that had rescued them and others off Libya to head for Europe.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: No Joke: Ukraine TV Comedian Wins Election’s First Round
item.media:description: Volodymyr Zelensky, center, a comedian, waiting for voting results at an election night gathering Sunday in Kiev.
item.description: Voters crowded into polling stations in a presidential race in which a leading candidate was a 41-year-old who plays a president on television.
item.dc:creator: IULIIA MENDEL and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: Afghan Vice President Survives Attack on Convoy
item.media:description: Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum, the vice president of Afghanistan, in Kabul last year. He has survived at least two other attacks by the Taliban, who blame him for the deaths of thousands of Taliban prisoners.
item.description: Gen. Abdul Rashid Dostum had predicted that the Taliban would set an ambush for him, and they did, killing at least one of his bodyguards.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and NAJIM RAHIM

item.title: North Korea Calls Raid at Its Embassy in Spain a ‘Terrorist Attack’
item.media:description: The North Korean Embassy in Madrid. Last month, an armed group attacked embassy employees, held them hostage and robbed them, a Spanish judge said.
item.description: After the break-in at its embassy in Madrid last month, North Korea said it was monitoring reports that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had been involved.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Paris Dispatch: The ‘Blue Prince of Montmartre,’ at 87, Still Rules Parisian Demimonde
item.media:description: Michou, center, at his cabaret in Montmartre. “I hope you’re enjoying your dinner,” he told the crowd. “If the meat is good, it’s because I slept with the butcher!”
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.description: Dressed habitually in blue, the silver-haired French icon Michou, the owner of Paris’s best-known cross-dressing cabaret, is a showman from a bygone era who still attracts adoring crowds.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN

item.title: News Analysis: Countries Want to Ban ‘Weaponized’ Social Media. What Would That Look Like?
item.media:description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern of New Zealand argues that there must be a middle ground in regulating social media.
item.description: No established democracies have ever come as close to applying such sweeping restrictions as Australia and New Zealand are considering in the wake of the Christchurch mosque shootings.
item.dc:creator: DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Russia Ordered a Killing That Made No Sense. Then the Assassin Started Talking.
item.media:description: The headstone of Ivan Mamchur, a Ukrainian prison guard and military veteran who was murdered in Rivne, a city in western Ukraine.
item.media:credit: Joseph Sywenkyj for The New York Times
item.description: It turned out the killer of a Ukrainian electrician was working for Russian intelligence agents.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL SCHWIRTZ

item.title: Trump Turns U.S. Policy in Central America on Its Head
item.media:description: Thousands of migrants, part of a caravan from Honduras, wave the Honduran, Guatemalan, and Mexican flags as they enter the Mexican state of Oaxaca in October. President Trump announced a plan to cut off aid to three Central American countries for failing to stop the flow of migrants toward the United States.
item.description: His plan to cut aid to Guatemala, Honduras and El Salvador is “shooting yourself in the foot,” said one human rights worker. Mexico has urged more funding for development.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Bezos’ Security Consultant Accuses Saudis of Hacking the Amazon C.E.O.’s Phone
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos’s security consultant accused the Saudi government of hacking the Amazon chief executive’s phone.
item.description: The accusations by Gavin de Becker, Mr. Bezos’ longtime security consultant, are the latest twist in a bizarre situation that has also pulled in the largest U.S. tabloid publisher and The Washington Post.
item.dc:creator: KAREN WEISE

item.title: Zuzana Caputova Is Elected Slovakia’s First Female President
item.media:description: Zuzana Caputova in Bratislava, Slovakia, this month. As a presidential candidate, she vowed to return a sense of decency to the country’s often toxic political climate.
item.description: Riding a wave of popular discontent over widespread corruption, she vowed to return a sense of decency to the country’s often toxic political climate.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA and MIROSLAVA GERMANOVA

item.title: A Leonardo Made a $450 Million Splash. Now There’s No Sign of It.
item.media:description: A scheduled unveiling of the painting last September was canceled without explanation. The Abu Dhabi culture department is refusing to answer questions.
item.description: Since a Saudi royal, most likely the crown prince, paid $450 million for “Salvator Mundi,” it has vanished from view, and museums hoping to show it say they don’t know where it is.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.category: Bader bin Abdullah bin Mohammed bin Farhan al-Saud

item.title: How Pain Tolerance and Anxiety Seem to Be Connected
item.media:description: Jo Cameron has a rare disorder in which she experiences no pain or anxiety, raising questions about the links between physical and psychological pain.
item.media:credit: Mary Turner for The New York Times
item.description: An article about the case of a woman who feels little pain or anxiety raised many questions, such as: Do low-anxiety people seem to feel less pain?
item.dc:creator: HEATHER MURPHY

item.title: Egypt Sentences 30 Men Over Church Attack Plot
item.media:description: The funeral for the victims in the Palm Sunday suicide bombing at St. Marks Cathedral in Alexandria, Egypt, in 2017.
item.description: Thirty men were sentenced to between 10 years to life imprisonment for planning a suicide bombing on a church in the Egyptian city of Alexandria.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: What’s the Secret to Reaching 111? ‘Avoid Dying,’ but ‘Porridge Is Helpful’
item.media:description: Bob Weighton turned 111 on Friday, the day Britain was supposed to leave the European Union. He called the political deadlock over the process “a total mess.”
item.media:credit: Steve Parsons/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: Alfred Smith and Bob Weighton were both born on March 29, 1908. But Britain’s oldest men say they’re as puzzled as anyone about the secret to longevity.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Afghan National Security Chief Is Sidelined in His Own War
item.media:description: The Afghan frustration with the United States has created an impasse that now threatens to further isolate President Ashraf Ghani at a delicate stage in negotiations with the Taliban, which his government has yet to participate in.
item.description: As the Americans negotiate with the Taliban directly, they are shunning Afghanistan’s national security adviser — and perhaps the president as well.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and MUJIB MASHAL
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: As Venezuelan Economy Unravels, Maduro Opponents Hope Downturn Will Topple Him
item.media:description: An iron plant in Guayana, Venezuela, that was paralyzed by the crippling national blackout that lasted almost five days and wiped out what little was left of Venezuela’s heavy industry.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The prolonged national blackout this month pushed the country closer to the brink of economic collapse. Inflation is expected reach 51 million percent this year.
item.dc:creator: ANATOLY KURMANAEV and MARIA RAMÍREZ

item.title: Protest at Gaza Fence Is Mostly Peaceful as Both Sides Urge Restraint
item.media:description: A protester used a slingshot to hurl a rock toward Israeli forces as Palestinians marked the anniversary of the “March of Return” border protests in Gaza on Saturday.
item.description: Tens of thousands of Palestinians marked the first anniversary of protests that have frequently led to violence. Three Palestinians were killed.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER and IYAD ABUHEWEILA

item.title: Ukrainians Vote, in Europe’s Only Country at War
item.media:description: A campaign billboard for President Petro O. Poroshenko in Kiev, Ukraine. He was elected in 2014, just three months after an uprising.
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.description: Five years after a revolution, Ukrainians are less thankful for their new leaders than for the freedom to vote them out of power.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER and BRENDAN HOFFMAN

item.title: Italy’s Deal With China Signals a Shift as U.S. Influence Recedes
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China with Prime Minister Giuseppe Conte of Italy in Rome last week.
item.description: Far from being isolated in Europe, the Italians say they are leading the expansion of new relations with China, and fully expect others to follow.
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: ‘In Afghanistan, We Laugh Differently’
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times
item.description: For a handful of teenage girls, robotics offered a reprieve from their violent, patriarchal country. Now they are back home, with the Taliban poised to gain power.
item.dc:creator: DANNA HARMAN and ANDREA DICENZO
